Fig. 1 Catalyst light-off in the CO oxidation reaction (heating curves) recorded in the PTA mode: (a) 7Co/6Ce/OLS; (b) 6Ce/7Co/OLS; (c) 6Ce/OLS; (d) 7Co/OLS. The insets show an enlarged area of the temperature range. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Comparison of the T50 values for the samples under study. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Light-off curves for the oxidation of CO and hydrocarbons over the 6Ce/7Co/OLS sample. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Low-temperature nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms for the 7Co/6Ce/OLS and 6Ce/7Co/OLS samples. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 TEM images of the as-prepared 7Co/6Ce/OLS sample. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Elemental mapping of the samples under study: (a) 7Co/6Ce/OLS, as-prepared; (b) 7Co/6Ce/OLS, after PTA; (c) 6Ce/7Co/OLS, as-prepared; (d) 6Ce/7Co/OLS, after PTA. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 XRD patterns of the samples before and after catalytic tests in the PTA mode: (a) 7Co/6Ce/OLS; (b) 6Ce/7Co/OLS. The reference data are taken from the PDF2 database. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 H2-TPR profiles for the samples before (a) and after (b) catalytic tests in the PTA mode. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 XPS spectra (Co 2p region) of the as-prepared and tested samples: (a) 7Co/6Ce/OLS; (b) 6Ce/7Co/OLS. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 XPS spectra (Ce 3d region) of the as-prepared and tested samples: (a) 7Co/6Ce/OLS; (b) 6Ce/7Co/OLS. Fig. 10 Fig. 11 (a) Diffuse reflectance UV–vis spectra of the 6Ce/7Co/OLS and 6Ce/OLS samples. (b) Relative content of Co3O4 in the 6Ce/7Co/OLS sample calcined at various temperatures. Fig. 11 Fig. 12 High-resolution TEM images of the samples after catalytic tests in the PTA mode: (a-c) 7Co/6Ce/OLS; (d-f) 6Ce/7Co/OLS. Vedyagin Writing – review & editing Conceptualization a ⁎ a Boreskov Institute of Catalysis, Novosibirsk 630090, Russia Boreskov Institute of Catalysis Novosibirsk 630090 Russia Boreskov Institute of Catalysis, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russia b Ioffe Institute, St. Petersburg 194021, Russia Ioffe Institute St. Petersburg 194021 Russia Ioffe Institute, 194021 St. Petersburg, Russia c Lomonosov Moscow State University, Moscow 119991, Russia Lomonosov Moscow State University Moscow 119991 Russia Lomonosov Moscow State University, 119991 Moscow, Russia ⁎ Corresponding author. Opal-like silica, which represents a new class of SiO2-based nanomaterials, was used as a support for the deposition of cobalt and cerium oxides as active components. A series of samples was prepared and tested in the oxidation of CO and hydrocarbons in a prompt thermal aging regime. As revealed by a set of physicochemical methods, the initial catalytic performance of the samples is high (T50 = 214 °С) due to the emergence of new catalytic sites, which appeared as a result of interaction between Co and Ce oxides located between silica nanospheres in a close proximity to each other. At 800 °C, these particles undergo agglomeration, which is expressed in a slight deactivation of the catalysts (T50 ≥ 260 °С). The bulk silicate phase is formed at 900 °C, thus leading to further deactivation. Recovering of the catalytic activity (T50 = 252 °С) takes place at 1000 °С. Graphical Abstract Keywords Cobalt Ceria Opal-like silica Prompt thermal aging Catalytic oxidation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Nowadays, vehicle exhaust gases and emissions from industry make a dominant contribution to global environmental pollution by such contaminants as carbon monoxide and volatile organic compounds (VOC). Therefore, decreasing such negative impact on the atmosphere remains to be a relevant task. In order to meet the continuously toughening standards for the neutralization level of contaminants [1], the researchers are focused on the development of efficient catalytic emission control systems [2–4]. The exact composition of the vehicle exhaust gases depends on the type of the engine but the main contaminants are unburnt hydrocarbons, CO, nitrogen oxides, and particulate matter. Typically, three-way catalysts (TWC), used in the case of gasoline engines, and diesel oxidation catalysts (DOCs), applied in the case of diesel engines, contain precious metals such as Pt, Pd, and/or Rh distributed on the surface of oxide supports such as alumina, zirconia, ceria, or their mixtures [5–8]. The main advantages of using platinum-group metals (PGM) in the mentioned catalysts are that they possess excellent catalytic activity and high-temperature stability. However, due to the high price and rarity of PGM and issues with the environmental sustainability of their production [9,10], it is desirable to substitute PGM with non-precious metals. So far, this goal is not reached yet. The main challenge here is to maintain an appropriate catalytic performance of the catalysts exploited under harsh conditions that include the presence of water vapor and high temperatures (800 °C and above [3]). Among non-precious metals that possess high catalytic activity in oxidation processes, Mn, Cu, Co, Ni, and Fe are studied more frequently. The use of these metals for the efficient conversion of CO and hydrocarbons was numerously reported in the literature [11,12]. About 50 years ago, Kummer [13] compared the oxidation activity of a number of non-precious metal oxides. As reported, Co3O4 possesses the highest relative activity in the oxidation of various hydrocarbons (methane, ethylene, etc.) and the activity in CO oxidation, which is comparable to CuO. Even earlier, in 1966, Boreskov obtained a sequence for the case of methane oxidation, which correlates well with the binding energy of oxygen on the surface of an oxide: Co3O4 > MnO2 > NiO > CuO > Cr2O3 > Fe2O3 [14]. In 2009, Yu et al. [15] reported that the catalytic activity of metal oxides in CO oxidation decreased in the following order: Co3O4 > MnO2 > NiO > CuO > Fe2O3 > Mn2O3 > Fe3O4 > CeO2 > TiO2. Since then, the superior performance of cobalt oxides in the oxidation of CO and hydrocarbons was reported by many researchers [16–19]. Thus, according to the literature data, Co3O4 is the most promising candidate to be considered an active component for the purification of exhaust gases containing CO and hydrocarbons. It should be noted that cobalt oxide exhibits excellent catalytic activity in the CO oxidation reaction at low temperatures, even below 0 °C [15,20–23]. As reported, the catalytic performance of Co3O4 particles is greatly influenced by their morphology. In particular, notable catalytic characteristics are demonstrated by Co3O4 in the form of nanorods. This type of morphology predominantly exposes the (110) planes of the spinel-type oxide, thus favoring the presence of active Co3+ species on the surface [20,23]. Indeed, it was found that Co3+ species are active sites for CO oxidation rather than Co2+, and the three-coordinated surface oxygen bonded with three Co3+ is more reactive compared to other types of surface oxygen [21]. Doping of cobalt oxide with various transition metals leads to the distortion of the crystal lattice and the appearance of oxygen vacancies, which can improve the performance of Co3O4-based catalysts in terms of activity in the oxidation of CO and hydrocarbons, stability, and humidity resistance [24–26]. In most cases, efficient catalytic performance of non-precious metals in oxidation processes can be achieved when oxides of these metals are coupled with CeO2 [27,28]. Ceria is known to possess excellent oxygen mobility along with a high oxygen storage capacity. The interaction of CeO2 with Co3O4 can lead to significantly higher reactivity compared to pure Co3O4, which is due to the formation of surface oxygen vacancies and an improvement in oxygen mobility [29–31]. Co3O4 can be stabilized over CeO2 in a highly dispersed state, which also positively impacts the catalytic activity. In addition, it was shown that in the presence of CeO2, cobalt retains its higher oxidation state [32,33]. Sui et al. [34] have reported that the catalytic performance of cobalt-ceria catalysts is notably influenced by the preparation method. The morphology of CeO2 used as a support was found to affect the strength of CoOx-CeO2 interactions. As shown by Huang et al. [35], CoOx supported on CeO2, which possesses a three-dimensionally ordered mesoporous structure, has higher surface vacancy concentration and surface area compared to CoOx supported on cubic or tube-shape ceria. Xie et al. [36] showed that rod-shaped particles of CoOx-CeO2 composite are more active compared to cubic particles. In the first case, the (100) and (110) planes are exposed to reactants, while in the cubic particles, the (111) planes are predominant. These results indicate that the interaction of CoOx with the (111) planes of CeO2 is much weaker. At the same time, the CoOx-CeO2 systems, due to their relatively low resistance to sintering, may not be suitable for high-temperature applications. In order to increase the thermal resistance of such systems, a more thermally stable material, such as SiO2, TiO2, or Al2O3, can be used as a primary support [37–39]. Silica is one of the most attractive materials for this purpose since it possesses a high surface area and a controllable porosity. In particular, the silica supports with an ordered structure (SBA-15, MCM-41, etc.) have been widely exploited by researchers [40–43]. Recently, macroporous silica materials with an opal structure were proposed as inert matrices for the synthesis of Co-Ce catalysts for CO oxidation, including preferential oxidation of CO in a hydrogen-rich mixture [44–46]. These materials were shown to have advantages in comparison with microporous and micro-mesoporous counterparts. In the latter case, the stronger Co3O4-SiO2 and CeO2-SiO2 interactions define the lower activity of the catalyst. When opal-like silica (OLS) with a low surface area was used, the Co3O4-CeO2 interactions were favored with relation to the Co3O4-SiO2 and CeO2-SiO2 interactions and the Co3+/Co2+ ratio was increased. The confinement of the oxides between the silica particles was assumed to be responsible for this kind of interactions. Thus, the OLS matrix can be considered a nanoreactor, which provides appropriate CoOx-CeO2 interactions. Another important characteristic of OLS materials is their high thermal stability. However, both cobalt and cerium oxides can undergo sintering at elevated temperatures, thus facilitating new interactions between the components. Therefore, the aim of the present study was to optimize the performance of the Co- and Ce-decorated OLS materials in terms of thermal stability. The prepared and studied materials include the two-component samples Co/Ce/OLS and Ce/Co/OLS and the reference samples Co/OLS and Ce/OLS. In the first case, the samples contain the same amount of deposited oxides but differ in the sequence of the support impregnation with the precursors. On the other hand, the CO oxidation rate can be influenced significantly by the other components present in the reaction mixture, such as NO and hydrocarbons [47,48]. In the present work, both the catalytic activity and stability were evaluated in a prompt thermal aging (PTA) mode, which consists of a number of temperature-programmed heating/cooling cycles in a reaction mixture containing CO, methane, propylene, toluene, NO, oxygen, and balance nitrogen. Comprehensive characterization of the materials before and after PTA tests using a set of methods, such as X-ray diffraction analysis, transmission electron microscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, diffuse reflectance UV–vis spectroscopy, and temperature-programmed reduction, allowed establishing the relationships between the structure of the catalysts and their catalytic performance. 2 Material and methods 2.1 Synthesis of the materials In the present research, opal-like silica (OLS), represented by close-packed non-porous amorphous silica (a-SiO2) particles, was used as a support. Silica particles with a diameter of 850 ± 40 nm were synthesized via basic hydrolysis of tetraethoxysilane (TEOS) in a mixture of NH3–H2O–C2H5OH, as described elsewhere [49]. OLS was grown from an aqueous suspension of the silica particles by sedimentation. The resulting sediment was dried at 100 °C and annealed at 800 °C in air. The volume available for filling was up to 26 % of the total OLS volume, and the specific surface area, estimated by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method, was 11 m2/g [45]. The method of introduction of oxides into the porous volume of OLS is described in detail elsewhere [45]. Cobalt oxide was introduced into the pores of OLS by a capillary impregnation with an aqueous solution of Co(NO3)2∙6 H2O under ambient conditions with the subsequent drying and annealing at 400 °C in air for 2 h. The sample was labeled as 7Co/OLS. To introduce cerium oxide, OLS was impregnated with an aqueous solution of Ce(CH3COO)3⋅1.5 H2O under ambient conditions. Then, the obtained material was dried and annealed at 400 °C in air for 2 h. This sample was denoted as 6Ce/OLS. Bimetallic Co-Ce samples were prepared similarly by the step-by-step introduction of the corresponding oxides with an intermediate drying between the impregnation procedures. Depending on the order of deposition, the samples were labeled as 7Co/6Ce/OLS (Ce introduced first) and 6Ce/7Co/OLS (Co introduced first). The contents of Co (7 wt%) and Ce (6 wt%) in all composites were assigned based on the mass ratio of silica and cobalt nitrate or cerium acetate, respectively. 2.2 Testing the catalytic performance The high-temperature catalytic performance of the prepared samples was examined in a prompt thermal aging (PTA) regime [50,51]. The catalytic oxidation of CO was used as a model reaction. The experimental setup consists of a system for regulating and monitoring the gas flows, a flow-through quartz reactor, analytical devices, and temperature controllers. In a typical test, a specimen (100 mg) in powder form (fraction of ∼ 0.2 mm) was loaded into the reactor. Then, the reactor was fed with the reaction mixture containing 14.0 vol% O2, 0.15 vol% CO, 100 ppm NO, 30 ppm CH4, 40 ppm C3H6, 11 ppm C6H5CH3, and balance N2. Such a mixture is close in composition to vehicle emissions and industrial exhaust gases. The total flow rate was 334 mL/min. Each sample was tested in eleven heating-cooling cycles (runs) with a varied final temperature, as shown in Table 1. The reactor was heated from 50 °C to the final temperature with a ramping rate of 10 °C/min. The CO concentration at the reactor outlet was analyzed every 5 s using an Ultramat 6 gas analyzer (Siemens, Germany). The heating curves of the catalyst light-off were analyzed and the temperature of 50 % conversion of CO (T50) was used as a criterion for the comparison of activity and stability of the catalysts. To investigate the simultaneous oxidation of CO and hydrocarbons, the same experimental setup and the same reaction conditions were employed. The reaction was studied in the temperature range of 150–600 °C. The reactor was heated to the desired temperature and maintained for 20 min before analytical sampling. The concentrations of methane, propylene, and toluene at the reactor outlet were measured using a Crystal-2000M gas chromatograph (Chromatec Instruments, Russia) equipped with a flame-ionization detector. At each temperature point, the conversions of CO and hydrocarbons were calculated. 2.3 Characterization of the materials The composition of the samples was determined by the method of atomic emission spectroscopy (AES) with inductively coupled plasma using an iCAP 6300 Duo spectrometer (Thermo Electron Corp., USA). Textural characteristics of the samples, such as specific surface area (SSA) and total pore volume (Vtotal), were determined via nitrogen adsorption/desorption at 77 K. The isotherms were recorded using a Sync200 instrument (3 P instruments, Odelzhausen, Germany). The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method was used to calculate the surface area values. The total pore volume was determined from the maximum adsorption value at P/P0 = 0.99. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis of the samples was performed using a D2 Phaser diffractometer (Bruker, Germany) with CuKα radiation. The average coherent scattering area sizes were calculated with the use of the Scherrer equation (Eq. 1). (1) D vol = λ β IB ⋅ cos θ where D vol is the mean size of the ordered domain, λ is the wavelength, θ is the Bragg angle, β IB is the integral breadth. The accuracy was about 1 %. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis of the samples before and after catalytic tests was performed with an Axis Ultra DLD spectrometer (Kratos Analytical Limited, UK) using characteristic binding energy of 103.6 eV (Si 2p) for spectra calibration, as described elsewhere [45]. Since the reduction of cerium on the surface of the samples occurs under the action of radiation, each XPS experiment started with the fast (about 100 s) acquisition of the Ce 3d spectra. The binding energies of the Ce3+ and Ce4+ components of the Ce 3d5/2 spectrum were varied in the ranges of 880.9–881.2 and 882.7–882.9 eV, respectively, as described for cerium-containing systems [52]. The components with binding energies in the ranges 781.2–781.7 and 779.7–780.2 eV of the Co 2p3/2 spectrum are assigned to the Co2+ and Co3+ states, respectively, in accordance with the literature data [53,54]. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) studies were carried out using a JEM-2100F microscope (Jeol, Japan) equipped with an energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectrometer. The samples were also characterized by the method of temperature-programmed reduction in hydrogen (H2-TPR). A specimen (∼340 mg) was fixed inside a quartz reactor with an inner diameter of 5 mm. The reactor was purged with a gas mixture containing 10 vol% H2 in nitrogen. The flow rate was 57.3 mL/min. After maintaining the reactor for 15 min, it was heated up to 850 °C with a ramping rate of 20 °C/min. The outlet hydrogen concentration was monitored using a GAMMA-100 gas analyzer (Analitpribor, Russia). The concentration profiles were integrated and the hydrogen uptake values were calculated. Diffuse reflectance UV–vis spectra were recorded in the range of 190–800 nm using a Varian Cary 300 UV/VIS Bio UV–vis spectrometer (Agilent Technologies, USA). The spectrometer is equipped with a Labsphere DRA-CA-3300 integrating sphere (Labsphere, USA). The Spectralon® standard was used as a reference. Before the characterization, all samples were uniformly homogenized in a mortar. The obtained UV–vis spectra were transformed into the Kubelka–Munk function (Eq. 2) [55]. (2) F(R∞) = (1 − R∞)2/2 R∞ = α/s where R∞ is the reflectance of an infinite sample, α is the absorption, and s is the scattering. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance of the metal-decorated OLS materials First, the catalytic performance of the metal-decorated OLS materials at the PTA conditions was examined. The observed light-off curves are collected in Fig. 1. It is important to emphasize that the composition of the reaction mixture significantly affects the behavior of the catalysts, which is reflected in the position of the light-off curves. For instance, in the case of oxidation of a sole CO in the mixture with oxygen and helium over the Co-decorated SiO2, the T50 values lie within a range of 110–128 °C [45]. In the presence of hydrocarbons, which are competitors for the active oxidation sites, the light-off curves are shifted to the high-temperature region, and all the T50 values are higher than 200 °C (Fig. 1). For descriptive reasons, the T50 values were plotted as a function of the catalytic run (cycle) number, as presented in Fig. 2. As seen in Fig. 1a, the light-off curves of CO oxidation over the 7Co/6Ce/OLS sample in eleven catalytic runs are located very closely to each other, thus indicating a high stability of the catalyst. The inset shows an enlarged area for the temperature range of 100–350 °C. The T50 values change within a narrow range from 214 to 263 °C (Fig. 2). A slight trend to deactivation is seen when the final temperature of the PTA run is as high as 800 °C. This deactivation stage is followed by the reactivation at 900 °C. The rearrangement of the cobalt oxide particles is assumed to be responsible for the deactivation/reactivation processes. It should be noted that all these light-off curves have a typical S-shape. Another picture is observed in the case of an opposite sequence of the metal oxide deposition (sample 6Ce/7Co/OLS, Fig. 1b). Here, the sample possesses higher activity in the first run (205 vs. 230 °C for 7Co/6Ce/OLS). However, the T50 values vary within a wider interval, ranging from 205 to 373 °C. In addition, starting from the seventh run, the shape of the curves differs from the S-shape. All these curves have a dip at temperatures above 600 °C. Moreover, in the ninth run, the CO conversion does not reach 100 %. Similar effects of hydrocarbon trapping followed by partial oxidation were reported previously for the zeolite-containing catalysts [56–58]. In those cases, such a behavior was explained by the release of an odd amount of CO via the partial oxidation of chemisorbed species of hydrocarbons. In general, the 6Ce/7Co/OLS catalyst also shows deactivation after the heating to 800 °C and reactivation at 900 °C (Fig. 2). However, the T50 value reaches 373 °C in the ninth run, thus showing more pronounced deactivation. Finally, being heated to 1000 °C, the catalyst exhibits the same T50 values as the 7Co/6Ce/OLS sample. In order to reveal the contribution of cerium and cobalt oxides to the observed catalytic performance, the reference samples, containing one oxide only, were tested at the same conditions. As seen in Fig. 1c, the 6Ce/OLS catalyst is significantly less active. The lowest T50 value for this sample of 440 °C was observed in the third run. Then, two deactivation stages can be distinguished (Fig. 2). The first one appears in the sixth run after the heating at 800 °C. The second deactivation stage is observed after the aging at 1000 °C. It should be noted that no dip in the light-off curves was observed for the ceria-only sample. This indicates that the unusual shape of the light-off curves exhibited by the 6Ce/7Co/OLS sample supposedly relates to the interaction of cobalt with the silica matrix. In order to confirm this supposition, the reference 7Co/OLS catalyst, containing cobalt oxide only, was tested. As shown in Fig. 1d, the typical S-shaped curves are observed in a number of catalytic runs, from the second to the seventh run, which practically coincide in their positions. Then, after aging at 900 °C, the light-off curves are seen to be shifted towards higher temperatures and changed in shape. The conversion of CO does not reach 100 % in the eighth and ninth runs. The T50 values for these runs are as high as 395 and 417 °C (Fig. 2). This high-temperature deactivation can be caused by the formation of some new phases, which are less active in the oxidation process. Note that the appearance of diffusion limitations cannot be excluded here. Finally, the observed reactivation of the samples aged at 1000 °C can be explained by the formation of new active cobalt species. Thus, it can be concluded from the data of catalytic tests that the activity of OLS decorated with cobalt and cerium oxides mostly relates to the active cobalt species. Fig. 3 shows the catalytic performance of the 6Ce/7Co/OLS catalyst, taken as an example, in the oxidation of CO and hydrocarbons. This sample was chosen due to its unusual behavior while testing in the PTA mode, as discussed above. As seen, the oxidation of propylene and toluene starts when almost 100 % conversion of CO is achieved. It is worth noting that the presence of CO in the reaction mixture has a significant effect on the oxidation kinetics of hydrocarbons. This complicates the direct comparison of the obtained data with the literature. Park et al. [59] tested the Co3O4@CeO2 catalyst with a core-shell structure in the joint oxidation of CO and propylene. Note that the composition of the reaction mixture was relatively close to that used in the present research. The T50 values exhibited by this catalyst in CO oxidation (203 °C) and propylene oxidation (241 °C) do not differ much from the values reported here (208 and 234 °C for the oxidation of CO and propylene, respectively). The oxidation of methane expectedly requires higher temperatures of ∼400 °C and above (Fig. 3). When no CO is present in the reaction mixture, methane oxidation over Co3O4-containing catalysts can occur starting from 300 °C [60] or even 200–250 °C [61,62]. 3.2 Characterization of the metal-decorated OLS In order to prove or refute the assumptions made, the catalysts under study were characterized by a set of physicochemical methods. First, the textural characteristics of the samples were examined. Fig. 4 shows the nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms for the OLS samples decorated with both cerium and cobalt oxides. The isotherms belong to Type II according to the IUPAC (International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry) classification [63], which is characteristic of macroporous materials. The SSA values for the 7Co/6Ce/OLS and 6Ce/7Co/OLS are 13 and 16 m2/g, respectively ( Table 2). It should be noted that the SSA of the undecorated OLS material was reported to be 11 m2/g [45]. The measured pore volume of the samples (Table 2) does not correspond to the full volume of the porous space between SiO2 particles. The macropores of 100–300 nm in size, which are also present in the material, can be filled with adsorbate and estimated only at the P/P0 values close to 1. As an example, TEM images presented in Fig. 5 show what the as-prepared 7Co/6Ce/OLS catalyst looks like. It is seen that the silica balls are covered with an oxide layer (Figs. 5a and 5b). As evident from Fig. 5c, this layer has a thickness of few tens nm. The uniformity of the distribution of cobalt and cerium oxides over the surface of OLS was examined by the elemental mapping of the samples. The obtained results are collected in Fig. 6. For the as-prepared 7Co/6Ce/OLS sample (Fig. 6a), cerium is seen to be distributed evenly. It should be noted that CeO2 covers the silica surface due to its interaction with the surface hydroxyl groups, as reported previously [44,46]. At the same time, the distribution of cobalt seems to be less uniform. After testing this catalyst under the PTA conditions, the aggregation of the cerium species is observed (Fig. 6b). The surface of OLS is partly denuded since the ceria coverage is not continuous anymore. Cobalt species are represented by large agglomerated particles as well as by highly dispersed species. Another situation is seen in the case of the 6Ce/7Co/OLS sample. In the as-prepared state, this sample exhibits a relatively uniform distribution of ceria (Fig. 6c). However, cobalt oxide is initially located in the form of coarse agglomerates in the junction points of the silica balls. In the aged state (after PTA), the sample looks similar to the tested 7Co/6Ce/OLS catalyst. The ceria layer covers the OLS surface unevenly, and a larger number of agglomerated Co species are found on the surface. The phase composition of these samples in the as-prepared and PTA-treated states was revealed by means of XRD analysis. The obtained XRD patterns are shown in Fig. 7. In the case when ceria was deposited on silica first (Fig. 7a), the pattern of the as-prepared sample shows low-intensive broad reflections assigned to CeO2 (at 28.6°, 33.1°, 47.5°, and 56.4°) and Co3O4 (at 31.3°, 36.9°, 44.9°, 59.5°, and 65.1°). The broadness of the XRD reflections indicates that the particles of both oxides are in a dispersed state. After the PTA tests, the patterns of the 7Co/6Ce/OLS sample changed significantly. The reflections from Co3O4 have disappeared almost completely. At the same time, the CeO2 reflections became narrow and more intensive, thus indicating the sintering and crystallization of this phase. Additionally, a new phase of Co2SiO4 with the main reflections at 25.3°, 32.1°, 34.5°, 35.5°, 36.4°, and 52.0° was detected. For the samples prepared using the reverse order of deposition of metal oxides, the detected phases are the same (Fig. 7b). However, the corresponding reflections differ in intensity and width. Thus, the reflections of the Co3O4 phase in the XRD pattern of the as-prepared 6Ce/7Co/OLS sample are more intense and narrower than that of the as-prepared 7Co/6Ce/OLS sample. This means that the initial dispersity of cobalt species is worse in this case. Oppositely, the tested 6Ce/7Co/OLS sample shows the XRD pattern, which practically coincides with that for the tested 7Co/6Ce/OLS catalyst. Taking into account the identical catalytic characteristics of these catalysts in the last two runs (Fig. 2), the coincidence of the phase composition and the dispersity of the present phases is quite expected. The observed peculiarities of the phase transformations taking place during the PTA tests can be explained by the following assumptions. As reported in the literature [64–67], the formation of the Co2SiO4 phase via the direct interaction of Co3O4 and SiO2 is proven to occur at a temperature of 900 °C. At lower temperatures, this phase can be formed from the salts-precursors only. Thus, the observed decrease in the catalytic performance in the cases of the 6Ce/7Co/OLS and 7Co/OLS samples (Fig. 2) can be due to the formation of a significantly less active phase of cobalt silicate. When ceria is present in the catalyst, it interacts strongly with cobalt species [68–70]. Therefore, 6Ce/7Co/OLS shows better activity (lower T50 value) than 7Co/OLS in the eighth run (Fig. 2). In the ninth run, due to the sintering and crystallization of the CeO2 phase, the released Co3O4 contacts and interacts with the silica matrix with the formation of a joint phase. In the absence of ceria, such interaction occurs already in the eighth run. In the case of the 7Co/6Ce/OLS catalyst, when the ceria layer prevents the direct contact of cobalt oxide with silica, the dispersed Co3O4 species remain on the surface and provide a high enough activity of the catalyst, even in the eighth and ninth runs. However, it should be noted that in all cases, a noticeable part of cobalt oxide participates in the formation of the silicate phase. One of the possible explanations for the reactivation effect observed in the tenth and eleventh runs is a partial decomposition of the silicate phase with the formation of dispersed cobalt particles. However, as seen from the CoO-SiO2 phase diagram reported by Zabdyr et al. [71], the Co2SiO4 bulk phase is stable up to 1600 °C. Nevertheless, it can be supposed that the silicate-like phase plays the role of an intermediate in the process of cobalt redispersion. Another explanation for the observed effects can dial with a partial blockage of the channels in the opal structure by the agglomerated particles of cobalt oxides. At 800–900 °C, the aggregation and sintering of cobalt oxide particles take place, thus causing mass transfer limitations. At 1000 °C, the facilitated interaction of CoOx with OLS spheres leads to the uncorking of the transport pores. In order to reveal the assumed interaction of cobalt oxide with ceria and silica, H2-TPR studies were performed. According to the literature [72,73], there are few species of cobalt oxide different in the reduction temperature that can be distinguished. Co3O4 is reduced via two stages (Co3O4 → CoO → Co), which proceed within a close temperature interval and, therefore, cannot be differentiated in the TPR profiles. The interaction of cobalt oxides with SiO2 can lead to the formation of joint phases, such as cobalt hydrosilicate and silicate. The latter are known to be reduced at temperatures below 1000 °C. The reduction of ceria is also a two-stage process. Within the temperature range of 400–500 °C, the surface oxygen species undergo the reduction, while at temperatures above 650 °C, the Ce4+ species in the bulk of the oxide are reduced to Ce3+ [74]. The interaction of Co3O4 with CeO2 results in the appearance of highly dispersed particles of cobalt oxide, characterized by a lower temperature interval of the reduction (below 300 °C) [74,75]. As shown in Fig. 8a, no evident hydrogen consumption within the studied temperature range is observed for the 6Ce/OLS sample. This can be explained by a relatively low concentration of ceria in the sample as well as by the fact that the reduction of ceria occurs in a wide temperature interval, which leads to a broadening of the TPR peaks. The TPR profiles of the as-prepared Co-containing catalysts demonstrate two peaks (Fig. 8a). Note that the second high-temperature peak has a shoulder in the high-temperature region. The main contribution to hydrogen consumption is obviously made by the two-stage reduction of Co3O4 to the metallic state (Eq. 1 and 2). The positions of the peaks are in good agreement with the literature [73]. (1) Co3O4 + H2 → 3CoO + H2O, T ∼ 300-370 °C (2) CoO + H2 →Co + H2O, T ∼ 370-450 °C The presence of the shoulder at 420–450 °C can be due to the inhomogeneity of the cobalt oxide particles in terms of their size and the character of their interaction with the support. The intensity of this shoulder decreases in the following order: 7Co/OLS > 7Co/6Ce/OLS > 6Ce/7Co/OLS. This testifies to the weakening of the CoOx-SiO2 interactions in the presence of ceria. The catalysts under study also differ in total hydrogen consumption. Supposedly, most of the cobalt in the 6Ce/7Co/OLS sample is in the form of Co3O4. The numerical data presented in Table 3 confirm this supposition. The TPR profile of the 7Co/OLS sample after PTA (Fig. 8b) contains just one peak of hydrogen uptake, which does not have a shoulder at ∼430 °C. This peak can be attributed to the CoO particles, noninteracting with silica. For the other two samples containing ceria, 7Co/6Ce/OLS and 6Ce/7Co/OLS, the intensity of this peak is noticeably lower. At the same time, a second peak at ∼850 °C, which can be supposedly assigned to the reduction of agglomerated CeO2 particles or cobalt silicate, is seen in the TPR profiles for these samples. However, it should be noted that temperatures of 900 °C can be required for the reduction of Co2SiO4 [76]. It is interesting to analyze the N(H2)/N(Co) values summarized in Table 3. It should be noted that the complete reduction of Co3O4 to metallic cobalt requires N(H2)/N(Co) = 1.33. Such a value was observed in the case of the as-prepared 6Ce/7Co/OLS sample only. The other samples 7Co/6Ce/OLS and 7Co/OLS show lower values. After testing the catalysts at the PTA conditions, all the N(H2)/N(Co) values are below 1. The highest ratio of 0.94 was calculated for the 7Co/OLS sample. Here, the observed decrease is evidently connected with the formation of the cobalt silicate phase, which cannot be reduced noticeably within the used temperature interval. For the ceria-containing samples, the ratio does not exceed 0.5. This observation indicates that a significant part of dispersed cobalt species still interacts strongly with the agglomerated ceria particles. The more precise information about the electronic state of elements was obtained by means of XPS. The survey spectra of the 7Co/6Ce/OLS and 6Ce/7Co/OLS samples in the as-prepared and tested states are presented in Figures S1 and S2 (Supplementary Information). All these spectra contain the spectral lines, corresponding to cerium, cobalt, oxygen, silicon, and carbon, and low-intensive lines related to nitrogen. The high-resolution spectra for the Co 2p and Ce 3d regions are shown in Figs. 9 and 10. The Co 2p and Ce 3d spectra were deconvoluted into the components related to various electronic states of metals. The calculated fractions of atoms in different states are summarized in Table 4. The Ce 3d spectra were also recorded with a short signal accumulation time at the beginning and the end of the XPS experiment. A comparison of these spectra indicates a noticeable reduction of cerium under the spectrometer conditions (Table 4). As obvious from the Co 2p spectra (Fig. 9), the as-prepared 7Co/6Ce/OLS and 6Ce/7Co/OLS samples contain almost the same amount of Co2+ and Co3+ species with an atomic ratio close to 1. Due to the formation of cobalt silicate during the PTA experiments, the predominant species in both the aged catalysts are Co2+ (Table 4). In all as-prepared and tested samples, cerium is mostly represented by CeO2, with a small amount of reduced Ce3+ species (Fig. 10, Table 4). The most informative are Co/Ce, Co/Si, and Ce/Si ratios. As seen in Table 4, the surface of the as-prepared 7Co/6Ce/OLS sample is, as expected, more enriched with cobalt than that of 6Ce/7Co/OLS. The high Co/Si ratio observed for this sample also testifies to the highest dispersion of the cobalt species. This agrees well with the elemental mapping data (Fig. 6a). At the same time, the Ce/Si ratios for these two samples are almost the same, which indicates that cerium is evenly distributed over the surface of OLS in both cases. After PTA, the Ce/Si ratios decreased more seriously than the Co/Si ratios. This observation confirms the previously made assumption about the thermal sintering and crystallization of cerium oxide. The highest Co/Ce ratios are exhibited by the 7Co/6Ce/OLS sample in the as-prepared state as well as after PTA. It should be noted that the sintering of ceria increases the portion of cobalt species on the surface, which are accessible for the reagents. At the same time, the surface concentration of cobalt decreases. In the next stage of the study, the samples were characterized by diffuse reflectance UV–vis spectroscopy. Additionally, the samples were diluted with SiO2 (SSA ∼ 400 m2/g), in order to avoid the optical effects of opal, and calcined at temperatures of 800–1000 °C. The typical UV–vis spectrum for SiO2 used for the dilution is shown in Figure S3. Also, Figure S3 presents the spectra for Co3O4 prepared via the calcination of Co(NO3)2·6 H2O at 550 °C in air and the reference sample 15 %Co/SiO2. It is evident that the absorption spectrum for 15 %Co/SiO2 is defined by the deposited cobalt oxide. This spectrum is characterized by the presence of two broad intensive bands at 415 and 700 nm, which correspond to the transitions 1A1 g→1T2 g and 1A1 g→1T1 g of Co3+ in octahedral positions of the Co3O4 spinel [77–79]. The band at 260 nm, which is absent in the case of bulk Co3O4 (Figure S3), can be assigned to the charge transfer for Co2+ in the octahedral symmetry for defects at the contact points between the Co3O4 and SiO2 particles. The position of this band differs from those typical for Co2+ in octahedron position in the cases of Co2SiO4 (200 nm) and CoO (280 nm). Fig. 11a compares the UV–vis spectra for the 6Ce/7Co/OLS and 6Ce/OLS samples. The 6Ce/7Co/OLS sample was also diluted with silica with a ratio of 1:6. The calcination of the diluted sample at the target temperature was performed for 6 h. As seen, after calcination at 800 °C, there is some increase in particle size of Co3O4 accompanied with a decrease in energy-gap width (Eg) from the initial value of ∼ 1.49 eV to ∼ 1.46 eV. The further rise of calcination temperature leads to the interaction of cobalt oxide with the SiO2 matrix. Along with this, the relative content of cobalt oxide in the 6Ce/7Co/OLS sample decreases with the temperature increase (Fig. 11b). The interaction process is followed by the rapid diffusion of Co2+ ions into the bulk of silica with the formation of the Co2SiO4 structure, in which Co2+ ions occupy non-equivalent octahedral structural sites M1 and M2. In this case, spectrum 5 in Fig. 11a shows a set of bands, which originated from spin-allowed d-d transitions of Co2+, 4T1 g(4F) → 4A2 g(4F) at 755 nm and 4T1 g(4F) → 4T1 g(4P) at 491–665 nm [80,81]. It should be noted that the bands in the range of 520–760 nm can also be attributed to d-d transitions of octahedral Co2+ in CoO [82]. The UV–vis spectrum of the 6Ce/OLS sample (spectrum 6 in Fig. 11a) consists of a broad band with a maximum at ∼ 300 nm, which is referred to as charge transfer bands for low-coordinated (LC) Ce3+ ions (LC O2− → Ce3+ charge transfer band at ∼ 265 nm), Ce4+ ions (LC O2− → Ce4+ charge transfer band at ∼ 280 nm), and interband transition from the O 2p → Ce 4 f band at ∼325 nm [83]. For the 6Ce/7Co/OLS sample, the intensity of the broad CeO2 band begins to decrease after the calcination at 1000 °C only, which can be due to the formation of Ce2Si2O7 [84]. It should be noted that the formation of cobalt silicate was also confirmed by TEM. Thus, Fig. 12 shows TEM images of the 7Co/6Ce/OLS and 6Ce/7Co/OLS samples after PTA tests. The presence of the Co2SiO4 phase is obvious from these micrographs. Besides this silicate phase, areas of SiO2, CeO2, and amorphous silicate are seen. At the same, it is important to note that the presence of cobalt oxides in these samples cannot be excluded due to very close values of interplanar spacing. Thus, such values for CoO and Co3O4 are 0.25 and 0.28 nm, respectively. Due to a high dispersity of these species, they cannot be registered by XRD. Finally, taking into account all the obtained results, it can be concluded that metal-decorated opal-like silica materials are promising candidates to be used as catalysts for the abatement of emissions of CO and volatile organic compounds. The OLS-based catalytic systems containing cobalt and cerium oxides can be exploited even at such high temperatures as 1000 °C. The deposition order of metal oxides does not affect the catalytic performance of the materials in the PTA runs with the final temperatures of 320–600 and 1000 °C (Fig. 2). A short-term deactivation of the catalysts was observed in the runs with the final temperatures of 800 and 900 °C. According to the results of UV–vis spectroscopy (Fig. 11a), the first deactivation stage at 800 °C is connected with the enlargement of Co3O4 particles. This process is less expressed when ceria is deposited on the OLS matrix first. Then, at 900 °C, the second deactivation stage, which is caused by the formation of a bulk cobalt silicate phase, occurred. Within this stage, the order, in which the metal oxides are deposited, matters. The direct contact of cobalt with the surface of silica facilitates this process. The formation of Co2SiO4 was proven by a set of methods, including XRD, XPS, UV–vis, and TEM. As for the reactivation effect observed in the PTA tests at 1000 °C, two explanations can be put forward. Firstly, the high-temperature aging of the samples is supposed to be responsible for the partial decomposition of the silicate phase and the appearance of highly dispersed cobalt species, which possess appropriate activity in the oxidation of CO and hydrocarbons. Such effect, however, has not been observed previously. As an alternative reason, the enlargement of Co oxide particles at 800–900 °C can block the pores in the opal structure. The intensive interaction of Co3O4 with SiO2 and the formation of Co2SiO4 at 1000 °C, as shown by UV–vis spectroscopy, can provide opening of the pores. In any case, the deactivation is found to have a temporary character. At the same time, the ceria component is assumed to undergo significant sintering and crystallization at temperatures of 800 °C and above. The agglomerates of highly crystallized ceria were registered by means of XRD and TEM. However, despite the contribution of ceria to the overall activity of the two-component catalyst is insignificant, the deposition of the first layer of ceria seems to be reasonable. First of all, the presence of such a layer enhances the dispersity of the active cobalt species and makes their distribution over the surface more uniform. The ceria layer strongly interacts with the hydroxyl groups on the surface of SiO2, thus providing the uniform coverage of silica [46]. Secondly, new active sites located at the CoOx-CeO2 interface can be formed. The presence of the CoOx-CeO2 interface in the samples after PTA is evident from the EDX data shown in Figures S4 and S5 (Supplementary Information). Finally, the ceria layer moderates the deactivation stage within the temperature interval of 800–900 °C. Thus, the 7Co/6Ce/OLS catalyst deserves consideration for further development. The comparison of the catalytic performance of the OLS-based catalysts with the supported cobalt catalysts studied previously is given in Table 5. It should be noted that the experimental conditions influence the catalytic activity greatly. In particular, the presence of hydrocarbons is crucial since they compete for the active adsorption sites on the catalyst’s surface. When no hydrocarbons are added to the reaction mixture, the activity of the Co/Ce oxide catalysts is expectedly higher (Table 5). Considering this fact, the initial catalytic performance of the cobalt-containing catalysts reported in the literature is comparable with the data obtained within the present research. In addition, the thermal stability of the OLS samples are much higher than that of the 15 %Co3O4/MgO catalyst studied previously [85]. The MgO-based sample showed significant deactivation starting from 800 °C. The excellent performance of the OLS-based materials investigated in the present research is believed to be due to a high thermal stability of the opal structure. 4 Conclusion In the present work, a series of catalysts based on the opal-like silica support was prepared and studied. This series includes two samples containing both cerium and cobalt oxides with different orders of their deposition and two reference samples, containing only ceria or cobalt oxide. All catalysts were tested in the oxidation of CO and hydrocarbons and examined by several characterization techniques. Using a prompt thermal aging regime to study the catalytic performance of the samples allowed us to reveal their thermal stability as well. Expectedly, cobalt oxide was shown to be necessary to provide high oxidation activity. The ceria-only sample oxidizes CO at significantly higher temperatures than all cobalt-containing samples. Moreover, cerium oxide demonstrated a trend to deactivate at 800 °C and above, which is due to its sintering and crystallization. All Co-containing catalysts exhibited high initial and final activity. At the same time, a short-term deactivation behavior, observed within the aging temperature range of 800–900 °C, was different. As revealed, the initial high activity of these samples is determined by the presence of dispersed Co3O4 particles. Their agglomeration at 800 °C was found to be a reason for the first stage of deactivation and can lead to the blockage of the pores in the opal structure. The second deactivation stage is connected with the interaction of cobalt oxide with the silica support and the formation of the cobalt silicate phase. The partial decomposition of this phase is thought to provide the appearance of dispersed cobalt species on the surface of the catalysts and reactivate them due to the stronger contact with CeO2. However, it should be emphasized that no clear information on the mechanism of redispersion of silica-supported cobalt oxide at 1000 °C is available in the literature, and the given explanation is more like a hypothesis. Despite ceria does not contribute to the activity of the catalysts directly, its presence as a first deposited layer enhances the initial dispersion of Co3O4 particles, minimizes their agglomeration at 800 °C and weakens their interaction with silica at 900 °C, thus providing enhanced activity within the studied temperature interval. The excellent thermal stability of the catalysts is provided by the opal-like structure of silica. coredata.dc:description: Opal-like silica, which represents a new class of SiO2-based nanomaterials, was used as a support for the deposition of cobalt and cerium oxides as active components. A series of samples was prepared and tested in the oxidation of CO and hydrocarbons in a prompt thermal aging regime. As revealed by a set of physicochemical methods, the initial catalytic performance of the samples is high (T50 = 214 °С) due to the emergence of new catalytic sites, which appeared as a result of interaction between Co and Ce oxides located between silica nanospheres in a close proximity to each other. At 800 °C, these particles undergo agglomeration, which is expressed in a slight deactivation of the catalysts (T50 ≥ 260 °С). The bulk silicate phase is formed at 900 °C, thus leading to further deactivation. Recovering of the catalytic activity (T50 = 252 °С) takes place at 1000 °С.

coredata.dc:title: Metal-decorated opal-like silica catalysts: High-temperature reconstructions in cobalt-ceria active layer during simultaneous oxidation of CO and hydrocarbons
